awd_titl_txt: Modeling the Active Site and Reactivity of Cyt. P450 Enzymes: A New Beginning
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Nicolai Lehnert of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Michigan will develop new classes of model systems for the active site of the Cytochrome P450 enzyme family. These enzymes play a key role in humans for the biosynthesis of steroids and the metabolism of drugs via the activation of inert C-H bonds, and are therefore of general interest for the pharmaceutical and chemical industry. The goal of this project is to build model systems that incorporate second coordination sphere effects of the protein matrix into the synthetic model systems.  The new model systems will then be used to (a) explore the molecular mechanism of O2 and NO activation by Cytochrome P450s, and (b) develop Cytochrome P450 biomimics as catalysts for industrial applications, in particular for O2 reduction in fuel cells, and C-H bond activation of organic molecules.  The project lies at the interface of inorganic, biological, and organic chemistry, and is therefore well suited to the education of scientists at all levels.  This research group is also well-positioned to provide summer research internships for underrepresented minority high school students from the Detroit area.  

Due to the great potential of cytochrome P450 for practical applications, a number of model systems have previously been created to mimic the heme-thiolate active sites of cytochrome P450s. However, most of these biomimetic complexes degrade readily in the presence of O2 or NO, even in the ferric (resting) state. This unexpected lack of stability is due to a valence tautomerism, where the ferric thiolate ground state of these complexes is in equilibrium with the ferrous thiyl state at room temperature. Based on these findings, this research group plans to investigate a new series of heme-thiolate model complexes that contain (a) hydrogen-bond stabilized thiolate ligands, and (b) different types of picket fence porphyrins, where 2nd coordination sphere effects are incorporated into the distal pockets of the model systems. This new series of complexes will be used to systematically investigate the reactivity of heme-thiolate active sites with O2 and NO to obtain detailed insight into how Cytochrome P450s activate O2 and NO. These investigations will be complemented with studies under heterogeneous conditions where the complexes will be immobilized on electrode surfaces, and their ability to electrocatalytically reduce O2 (fuel cell technology) and activate C-H bonds (synthesis) will be tested.

por.por_cntn:
Human activities lead to the massive release of several gases into the atmosphere that contribute to global warming. This includes carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4) and nitrous oxide (N2O). Nitrous oxide originates from agriculture, in particular the overfertilization of the soil with nitrogen-containing fertilizers (ammonia and inorganic nitrates). Here, nitrification is responsible for ammonia oxidation to nitrite and nitrate, and these nitrogen oxides are then picked up by denitrifying bacteria and fungi that live anaerobically in soil and sea water and that transform these species into N2O. Nitrous oxide is not only a greenhouse gas with a warming potential that is 300 times larger than that of CO2, but it is also an ozone-depleting agent. Therefore, there is currently a great interest in better understanding the processes in the soil responsible for N2O formation. Nitric oxide reductases (NORs) are the key enzymes responsible for the central transformation that generates N2O. In fungi, this process is mediated by the enzyme Cyt. P450nor, which belongs to the Cyt. P450 enzyme superfamily. Our mechanistic investigations on these enzymes therefore contribute to the currently ongoing, large efforts to better understand N2O generation resulting from denitrification, and what the impact of this process is for global warming.

 

Cyt. P450’s are important model enzymes for the development of green catalysts for applications in the synthesis of fine chemicals in the chemical and pharmaceutical industry. Cyt. P450s catalyze the oxidation, hydroxylation, epoxidation, dealkylation, etc. of hydrocarbon feedstocks, and due to their selectivity, can also be used for late stage functionalization in the synthesis of complicated organic molecules, especially drugs. Due to the environmentally detrimental effects of organic solvents, especially halogenated and aromatic compounds, there has been a major push for the usage of water in organic syntheses over the years. Elimination of organic solvents in chemical reactions is a core areas of Green Chemistry. Hence, there is a great interest in the chemical industry to develop either synthetic catalysts that are able to perform similar reactions as Cyt. P450s or apply engineered Cyt. P450s directly and then use water as the reaction medium. The work conducted under this grant makes key advances towards this goal. First, our research leads to a better understanding of (a) the role of the proximal thiolate (Cys) ligand for the properties of the active site of Cyt. P450s and for catalysis, and (b) how the hydrogen bonding network around the cysteine (the ‘Cys’ pocket) fine-tunes the properties of the heme. Our work therefore provides a handle for further catalyst optimization. This information is critical to design improved biomimetic oxidation catalysts based on Cyt. P450s and to improve engineered Cyt. P450s for use in organic syntheses at scale.

 

Another aspect closely related to the function of heme-containing enzymes is the currently ongoing search for electrocatalysts for hydrogen fuel cells that are based on inexpensive and abundant, first row transition metals. We are testing our new Cyt. P450 model systems for the direct, electrocatalytic four-electron reduction of O2 to water, which corresponds to the cathodic half reaction in hydrogen fuel cells. This work is conducted in direct collaboration with Prof. Abhishek Dey (Indian Association for the Cultivation of Science, Kolkata, India). In this way, our work makes key contributions to the development of improved hydrogen fuel cells for energy applications and transportation.

 

In summary, the overarching goal of this project is to learn and understand on a fundamental, molecular level how nature has tuned the Cyt. P450 active site for optimal catalysis (both in NO and O2 activation). In this project, we are focusing on one particular aspect of this topic, which are the properties of the unique, axial Cys ligand to the heme in these enzymes. Besides the knowledge gained through these studies, the design principles derived in this way can then be used to obtain better catalysts for applications in organic syntheses and O2 reduction electrocatalysis in fuel cells; the latter is an application that we have been actively pursuing as a part of this project.

 

Besides these scientific aspects, my outreach program with Cass Technical High School in Detroit that I started in Summer 2014 (UM Detroit Research Internship Summer Experience, D-RISE) has made important contributions to increase underrepresented minority representation in the sciences by motivating the participating students to attend college and to work in STEM areas. D-RISE provides 7 weeks full-time summer internships to high school students from Cass Tech in the UM Chemistry Department. The students all commented on the strong impact of this experience in giving them hands-on experience with real science, further motivating them to pursue STEM careers. In addition, working with high school students provides valuable mentoring opportunities to the participating graduate students and postdocs.
